body.p:
I employ my earliest leisure
in replying to yours of 30th ult, because
I wish to disabuse you of the idea you
seem to entertain that I had written some
of our Ministers in the states had invited
my cooperation in undertakings which
certainly would have injured you. But I
did not write this, No doubt you have
just grounds of complaint against some
—you are the best judge of this, but it
might have occurred to you that laymen
also might have made these overtures.
I wrote you in my last what I have
stated to you personally—that with reference
to the election I had been deemed guilty
of insincerity by you, because some
ministers had represented one thing to you
and another to me. Of this I have proof
but I bore the imputation (and have done
so until now) because I believed that if
your many professions of friendship &
esteem extending over 6 years had been

sincere, you had not deemed me guilty
of such meanness not to say irreligion.
You repeat, you did me no wrong. But
irrespective of your unwarrrantable attack in
the Occident you forget you wrote in here
to Mr J Joseph (?) that I had underhandedly
endeavored to supplant you. I have denied
and do as earnestly as ever deny this & convinced
as were all your best friends—Miss Gratz
included—that you had made unjustifiable
changes. You know yourself the change is
not a trifling one which you wrote to Mr
J H Joseph. And conscious of me, ?
you might suppose I could not congratulate
you on your decision or judgment or friendly
feeling. But Pope-like—excuse my candor—
You will be infallible. I have still Mr Josephs
letter wherein you write as above. I will trouble
you no more on this subject, but I believe the
day will yet come when you will admit that
you unwarrantably accused me, and also that
I was not “too foolish to act properly.” One
more remark however—you write—you would
have wished ministers to have acted towards
you, as they would have expected you to have
acted towards them. You no doubt imply I did
not so act. But I shall be satisfied if any
one coming here, when I have acted & said as you
did, shall act as underhandedly to me as I did to you.

I know of no plan concocted or concocting
that could injure you; nor have I heard of
any new magazine or periodical project.
I think however that the Orthodox Occident
is not sufficient for the wants of orthodoxy
although you are the first one I have ever
stated this much to—as otherwise I should
hear from you that I had been underhandedly ?
We want a weekly—a good spirited weekly
in the orthodox interest, that would give
? in a civil way the attention
the want oftener than once a month. If the
Asmonean were more of my way of thinking
I would like to see it flourish, but enterprising
& worthy man as Mr Lyons is, he has allowed
his paper to become too frequently the ?
of the most dangerous views, editorially as
well as by means of correspondents. Is there
any chance of you publishing a weekly.
I promise you not to supplant you in any way
otherwise don't be surprised if you find me
doing what I can for an orthodox weekly
one of these days. But perhaps the Asmoenan will prove a true ma
-cabee. I write to my father today & shall tell
him you had not heard from him to date.

they would do their share here for a
college but where is the action in more
important places?

I will do what I can in collecting
and remain Yours truly
